Key Arguments: The submission questions the very basis of the proposed legislation, arguing that misinformation and information are often indistinguishable and interchangeable.
The author suggests that humans and institutions are fallible and often incapable of accurately distinguishing between information and misinformation.
The submission highlights historical examples where widely accepted beliefs were later proven wrong, suggesting that what is considered misinformation can change over time.
The author argues that the legislation could suppress freedom of speech and hinder scientific and societal progress.
The submission critiques the reliance on institutions deemed credible by the bill, arguing that these institutions are also sources of misinformation.
Main Themes: Fallibility of human judgment and institutions
Historical shifts in what is considered true or false
Freedom of speech and its importance in societal progress
Critique of the proposed legislation's potential impact on open debate and innovation
Notable Quotes: The great tragedy of science — the slaying of a beautiful hypothesis by an ugly interpretation.

Suppression of so-called ‘misinformation’ and ‘disinformation’ poses a threat to the safety and wellbeing of Australians, as well as to our democracy, society, scientific advancement and the economy, and threatens freedom of speech itself.
Innovation, by definition, arises through alternative ways. Alternative ways stem from alternative views.
